alt_statements.statement: As a Cherokee man and a progressive Christian, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. Our people have seen how systems built long ago can silence certain voices, and today the Electoral College makes many votes—especially in safe states and among minorities—feel like they don’t matter. A straightforward popular vote would better reflect the will of all Americans and push candidates to listen to every community, not just a handful of swing states.

As someone who immigrated here and takes citizenship and tradition seriously, I think we should keep the Electoral College but make a few reforms to improve fairness. I’d support changes like allocating electors by congressional district or proportional to the statewide vote, rather than winner-takes-all, so people in both big cities and small towns feel their votes matter. This keeps the balance between states and the whole country, while reducing the sense that some states are ignored.

Given my belief in fairness and one-person-one-vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you’re in South Dakota or California. As someone who values democracy and feels frustrated when whole states are written off as “safe,” I’d support either a constitutional amendment to move to direct election of the president or, at minimum, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to ensure the winner is the person who actually gets the most votes nationwide.

As someone who values fairness and clear rules, I think we should seriously consider moving toward a national popular vote, or at least reforming the Electoral College so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally rather than winner-take-all. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and as a moderate voter in a family-focused, middle-of-the-country life, I’d like every individual vote—whether in Nebraska or New York—to count equally.

I’d be open to reforming the Electoral College, but I wouldn’t scrap it outright. A system like the one Maine and Nebraska use, where electoral votes are partly based on congressional districts and partly on the statewide result, seems like a fairer balance between giving smaller states like Wisconsin a voice and still reflecting the overall popular will.

Given how divided the country feels lately, I think we need reforms that make people feel their vote truly counts, no matter where they live. I’d support changes like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electoral votes so the final result better reflects the will of the majority, while still encouraging candidates to pay attention to smaller and rural states. That seems like a fairer balance between honoring our constitutional traditions and updating the system for today’s population and politics.

The Electoral College is an anachronism that undermines the principle of one person, one vote, and we should move to a national popular vote for president so that every ballot carries equal weight, whether it’s cast in Ohio or Hawaii. As someone who’s spent a career teaching students to value evidence and democratic norms, I’m troubled by how often the current system sidelines millions of voters in “safe” states and distorts campaigns around a handful of swing states. A direct popular vote, with strong national standards for ballot access and election security, would be more transparent, fair, and consistent with the pluralistic, multiracial democracy we claim to be.

As a Cherokee, a dad, and someone who works in our public schools, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they live in. My students learn that we’re all equal under the law, but the current system makes some votes matter more than others and pushes campaigns to ignore places like Oklahoma. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to all communities—including Native people and working families—rather than just a few swing states.

I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, so that every ballot—whether it’s cast in Iowa or California—counts the same. Working in a hospital and raising kids, I don’t have time to obsess over complicated systems, and it frustrates me that someone can win the presidency without getting the most votes. A straightforward popular vote feels more democratic and would push candidates to care about people in all states, not just a few swing ones.

Coming from Honduras, I’ve seen what it means when people feel their vote doesn’t truly count, and the Electoral College feels a bit like that to me. I think we should move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot has the same weight, no matter what state they live in. If that’s not possible right away, at least states should allocate electors proportionally instead of winner-take-all, so elections reflect the real diversity of voters’ choices.

In my kitchen, every customer counts the same, whether they order the cheapest noodle soup or the most expensive seafood, so in a big country like America I think every vote should also count the same in choosing the president. I would like to see the Electoral College changed to a national popular vote system, maybe with some protections so smaller and rural communities aren’t ignored, because small business people and immigrants like me shouldn’t feel like our voices disappear in a winner-take-all state. As a Catholic and a father, I believe in fairness and dignity, and a more direct vote feels closer to that—simple recipe, fewer tricks.

I don’t really understand all the details of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown-ups always tell us to play fair and not leave anyone out, so maybe we should have a system where the person with the most votes from all the people in the country wins.

I support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot carries equal weight no matter what state they live in. As someone who analyzes systems for a living, I see the current structure as inefficient, distortionary, and too vulnerable to outcomes that don’t reflect the will of the majority. A direct popular vote, backed by strong national voting standards and protections, would be a more democratic, transparent, and modern way to elect a president.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to know the Electoral College doesn’t reflect the will of the people the way it should. We ought to move to a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you’re in Alabama or California, and candidates can’t just ignore “safe” states. If that’s too big a leap for now, at the very least we should require states to allocate their electors proportionally instead of winner-take-all, so the final result better matches how people actually voted.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime organizing in communities and believes deeply in every person’s dignity, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote. One person, one vote ought to mean the candidate with the most votes wins, no matter where those votes come from—whether it’s rural New Mexico or downtown Chicago. The current system makes some states and communities matter more than others, and that goes against the democratic values I came to this country believing in. If a full replacement isn’t politically possible yet, at minimum we should adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us closer to true majority rule.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you live in Ohio like me or in a big coastal state. The Electoral College makes it feel like politicians only care about a handful of “swing states” instead of the whole country, and that doesn’t sit right with my belief in fairness and equal voice. If a full replacement isn’t possible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us in that direction.

I don’t totally understand all the big details, but I think it would be more fair if the person who gets the most votes from all the people in the country becomes president. That feels like when we vote in class for something and everyone’s vote counts the same, and then kids trust the result more.

I think the Electoral College mostly does what it was meant to do: make sure smaller states like Iowa still matter and big cities don’t completely run the show. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-by-state system but push states away from winner-take-all, maybe splitting electoral votes by congressional district so people in the minority party in each state still have a voice.

I think the Electoral College should mostly be kept, because it protects smaller states and more rural areas from being totally ignored by big cities. But I don’t like the “winner-take-all” system in most states, since that can make a lot of people’s votes feel pointless. I’d rather see states award electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally, so the final result still respects the states’ role but better reflects the actual voters’ choices.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the influence of smaller and rural states like my own Minnesota, but it could use some modernization. I’d favor reforms that keep the state-based system but encourage broader representation, such as states adopting proportional allocation of electors instead of winner-take-all, so that candidates have to earn support more widely without turning our elections into a simple big-city popular vote contest.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to feel that the Electoral College doesn’t reflect every vote equally, and that bothers me as someone who believes in basic fairness and one person, one vote. I’d like to see us move toward a national popular vote or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electors, so that every ballot in every state counts the same. For a democracy as old as ours, especially given our history with voting rights and racial inequality, it’s time our system caught up with the principle that the candidate with the most votes should win.

I don’t really understand all the rules about the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote for president counted the same, no matter what state they live in. My parents say that sometimes the person with fewer votes can still win, and that sounds wrong to me, so I’d want the rules changed so the person with the most votes always becomes president.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. Working construction and seeing how different people get treated, it bugs me that a few “swing states” basically decide everything while millions of votes elsewhere don’t really matter. A direct popular vote would push candidates to focus on the whole country instead of just certain states, and that feels more fair and democratic to me.

I don’t really understand the Electoral College, but I think everyone’s vote should just be counted the same, like when we vote in class and the choice with the most hands up wins. It feels fair if the person who gets the most votes becomes president, so people don’t feel like their voices don’t matter.

As a young dad and a Democrat, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you’re in a swing state or not. Coming from a working-class background, it doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, because it makes regular people feel like our voices don’t matter as much. If fully replacing it isn’t politically realistic, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electoral votes or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to make the system more democratic and fair.

At my age, I’ve seen enough elections to know the Electoral College doesn’t always reflect what most Americans actually want. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least reform the system so every vote counts equally no matter what state you live in. As a Democrat and a Christian, I believe in fairness and in every person’s voice mattering, and the current setup feels outdated and too easy to distort.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count equally no matter what state they live in. As a young Black woman in Georgia, it’s frustrating to see how much power a few swing states get while voices like mine can feel discounted. A popular vote would push candidates to actually care about turnout and issues everywhere, not just in certain states.

At my age, I’ve lived through enough elections to feel that the Electoral College no longer reflects the will of the people as it should. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in New Jersey or a small rural state, and candidates have to speak to the whole country, not just a few “swing” areas. If that’s too large a leap, at minimum we should require states to allocate electors proportionally, so the outcome more closely matches how citizens actually vote.

As someone who teaches national security and cares deeply about the stability of our institutions, I believe the Electoral College should be preserved but modestly reformed. A system where states adopt the Maine/Nebraska model of allocating electoral votes by congressional district, with a small bonus for the statewide winner, would better reflect the popular will while still ensuring that less populous states and diverse regions have a meaningful voice. This strikes me as a responsible balance between majority rule and the federalist structure the Founders intended.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. A national popular vote feels more fair, because then the candidate who most people actually choose becomes president, and that matches what we learn at church about everyone being equal and having a voice.

As someone who cares deeply about fairness and the environment, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot, whether cast in Utah or New York, counts equally. Right now, candidates chase a handful of swing states and mostly ignore issues that matter to many of us—like climate change and sustainable communities—unless those states care. A direct popular vote would push campaigns to talk to all Americans, not just the politically convenient few.

Given how deeply I care about fairness and every voice counting—values that shape both my politics and how I run things at the hospital—I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote. It doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and it feels especially undemocratic for people in “safe” states to feel like their ballots don’t matter. A direct popular vote, possibly with ranked-choice voting to ensure broad support for the winner, would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to pay attention to voters in every corner of the country.

I think the Electoral College should mostly be kept as it is, because it forces candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states instead of just big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to reforms like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around faithless electors so the system feels fairer and more accountable, without throwing out what has worked for a long time.

I think the Electoral College needs some updating, but not a full scrap-and-replace. I’d favor reforms like allocating electors proportionally or by congressional district, so every vote feels like it counts more without handing everything over to a pure national popular vote that would sideline smaller states and rural communities. The Founders built checks and balances for a reason, and I’d rather see us fine-tune that system than throw it out based on a few contentious election cycles.

As someone who became an American by choice, I believe every vote should carry the same weight, no matter where you live, so I favor moving toward a direct national popular vote for president. The Electoral College gives some states outsized influence and can silence the voices of people in more diverse, urban communities like the one I serve. At the very least, we should reform it—ending winner-take-all allocation in states and ensuring that the outcome can never contradict the national popular vote. That would better reflect our democratic values and show every citizen, natural-born or naturalized, that their voice truly matters.

Given my belief in community health and interconnectedness, I think our political system should also reflect the will of people as directly as possible. I’d favor replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, so every ballot counts equally no matter what state you live in. Short of that, reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting at the state level could at least reduce the distortion of winner-take-all rules and encourage candidates to engage more broadly with diverse communities.

As someone who became a U.S. citizen by choice, I think every single vote should count equally, no matter what state you live in, so I support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. The current system makes some states matter more than others, and that feels unfair and undemocratic, especially to immigrants and people of color whose voices are already often marginalized. A straightforward popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and push candidates to speak to all communities, not just “swing states.”

Como inmigrante que no puede votar, pero que ve cuánto afectan las decisiones del gobierno a las familias como la mía, siento que el sistema del Colegio Electoral no siempre refleja verdaderamente la voluntad de la gente. Me gustaría que el presidente se eligiera por voto popular directo, donde cada voto cuente igual sin importar el estado, para que las comunidades de inmigrantes y las personas sin poder político ni dinero tengan más peso. Un sistema más sencillo y justo también podría reducir la desconfianza y animar a más personas a involucrarse, incluso si, como yo, todavía no tienen ciudadanía.

As someone who believes in fairness and every voice counting equally, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It troubles me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and that some states get so much more attention than others while many voters feel ignored. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to speak to all Americans, not just those in a handful of swing states.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College is outdated and doesn’t reflect the “one person, one vote” ideal this country ought to live up to. I’d like to see it replaced with a national popular vote, or at least reformed so electoral votes are allocated proportionally within each state, so folks in every corner—urban, rural, red, blue—feel their vote actually counts.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. As someone who’s pretty environmentally minded and works hard for my paycheck, it doesn’t sit right that a few swing states get most of the attention while issues like climate, healthcare, and workers’ rights hinge on an outdated system. A direct popular vote would push candidates to campaign to all Americans, not just a handful of strategically important states.

As a naturalized citizen, I respect the stability the Electoral College has given this country, but I also value fairness and accountability. I would keep the Electoral College, but require every state to allocate its electors proportionally or by congressional district, so that more people feel their votes matter, not just those in a few swing states. This seems like a careful, conservative change that protects order while making representation a bit more balanced.

Given how diverse and interconnected our country is, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in Florida or a small rural state. As someone who works with people from many backgrounds and sees how hard they struggle just to be heard, it doesn’t sit right with me that a few swing states carry so much weight. At the very least, we should reform the system—eliminate winner-take-all rules, expand access to voting, and ensure that candidates have to earn support from the whole country, not just a handful of strategic states.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they’re from. As a young Black kid in the South, it feels wrong that a few swing states decide elections while a lot of people’s voices, especially in places like mine, don’t really matter as much. A popular vote would push candidates to care about communities everywhere, not just the ones that help them win the Electoral College.

The Electoral College is a core part of the constitutional system, and I don’t support scrapping it in favor of a pure popular vote that would let a handful of big cities decide every election. That said, I’d be open to modest reforms that keep the state-based structure—like tightening rules around faithless electors or improving how states allocate their electoral votes—so the process is more transparent and people trust the outcome.

At my age, I’ve seen too many elections where the Electoral College drowned out the voices of ordinary voters, especially in states that are safely red or blue, and that just doesn’t sit right with me. I’d prefer a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, whether you’re in Texas or Maine, Black or white, city or rural. If we can’t get all the way there yet, we should at least reform the system—like proportional allocation of electors—so campaigns have to earn support across the whole country instead of camping out in a handful of swing states.

I don’t totally get all the complicated parts of the Electoral College, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the most votes in the whole country and still lose the election. I think it would be better if every person’s vote counted the same no matter what state they live in, so the winner is whoever gets the most votes from all the people. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so smaller states still get heard, but not in a way that makes people feel like their vote doesn’t really matter.

As a civics-minded teacher and a Democrat, I think it’s hard to justify telling my students that every vote matters equally when the Electoral College does the opposite. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote for president, or at least adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that the candidate with the most votes actually wins. That would better reflect basic democratic fairness and make it easier to explain our system to young people who are already skeptical about whether their participation counts.

Coming from Spain, where the head of government is chosen through parliamentary elections rather than something like the U.S. Electoral College, I find it strange that a candidate can win fewer popular votes but still become president. I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every vote counts equally regardless of state, which feels more democratic and consistent with my left-leaning values. A direct popular vote would also likely encourage higher participation and make young, diverse, and urban voices like mine matter more in the outcome.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so the person who gets the most votes from people across the whole country becomes president, because that feels more fair and easier to understand. It seems weird that someone could lose the popular vote but still win, and if every vote counted the same no matter what state you live in, kids like me might feel like our future is decided more equally for everyone.

I think the Electoral College is kind of confusing and feels unfair, because sometimes the person with the most votes doesn’t even win. I’d rather have a simple popular vote so every person’s vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. That seems more honest and easier for people my age to understand and trust.

Given how much I care about teaching and evidence-based policy, I think we should move toward a national popular vote for president, or at least significantly reform the Electoral College—such as adopting proportional allocation of electors—so every vote counts equally regardless of state. The current system distorts campaigns around a few swing states and can produce outcomes that don’t reflect the national popular will, which undermines democratic legitimacy.

As a young mom, I want a system where every vote for my kids’ future truly counts the same, no matter what state we live in, so I lean toward replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. At the same time, I care about keeping our country stable and united, so any reform should be gradual and carefully designed to protect smaller communities and make sure family-focused issues still get real attention from candidates.

As someone who runs a small ad agency and believes in reaching people directly, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes campaigns focus on a handful of swing states and leaves a lot of everyday voices—especially younger, more diverse, and urban communities—on the sidelines. A straightforward popular vote would feel more democratic, encourage higher turnout, and better reflect the actual will of the people.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe we should move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether they live in California like me or in a small rural state. The Electoral College can drown out the voices of millions of voters, especially people of color and those in safe states, and that doesn’t sit right with my Christian sense of fairness or my democratic values. I’d support a straightforward reform where the presidency goes to whoever wins the most votes nationwide, possibly phased in through agreements like the National Popular Vote Compact so we respect the Constitution while making the system more just.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they’re in. Growing up hearing about voting rights and inequality, it just feels wrong that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote. A popular vote system would push candidates to care about all communities, not just a handful of swing states, which seems more fair and more democratic.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but with some updates to make folks feel their vote really counts, like tightening rules around how states handle electors and increasing transparency. It protects smaller states and rural areas like where I’m from from being steamrolled by big cities, and I don’t want presidential races decided only by New York, California, and a few big urban centers. If anything, I’d support reforms that strengthen the system against fraud and backroom deals, not scrapping it for a pure popular vote.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but it could use some tightening around things like faithless electors so they’re bound to the people’s vote in their state. Our country is a union of states, not just a collection of big cities, and the current system helps make sure smaller and rural states like mine still have a voice. A straight national popular vote would hand too much power to the biggest population centers and ignore the values of folks in the rest of the country.

I think the Electoral College should stay, because it makes sure smaller and more rural states like Kentucky still have a voice instead of everything being decided by big cities on the coasts. If anything, we should focus on cleaning up voter rolls, tightening ID laws, and making the process more secure and transparent, not blowing up a system that’s worked for over 200 years.

As a progressive and a software developer who thinks a lot about systems, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot is weighted equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system encourages candidates to focus on a handful of swing states while sidelining diverse communities like mine, and that’s fundamentally out of step with democratic values. At minimum, I’d support reforms such as the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors as steps toward a fairer, more representative system.

Given how much technology and data we now have, the Electoral College feels like an outdated mechanism that distorts the principle of “one person, one vote.” I’d prefer a national popular vote with some form of ranked-choice voting, so every ballot directly shapes the outcome and third-party or independent candidates can participate without being spoilers. As someone who came to the U.S. from India and works in a data-driven field, the current system’s reliance on a handful of swing states looks both statistically inefficient and structurally unfair. Reforming it would make the system more representative and reduce the sense that some votes matter far more than others.

As someone who believes in fairness and social equality, I think we should move toward a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether you live in Ohio or a swing state. The Electoral College makes it feel like some votes matter more than others, and that just doesn’t sit right with me as a mom trying to teach my kids about real democracy. At the very least, we should reform it so electoral votes are awarded proportionally in each state instead of winner-take-all, which would better reflect the actual will of the people.

As a political science professor and a Democrat who values both majority rule and minority rights, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote for president. Every citizen’s vote ought to have equal weight regardless of state, which would encourage candidates to campaign across the whole country instead of just in swing states. A well-designed national popular vote, paired with strong protections for voting rights and election administration standards, would both honor our democratic ideals and increase the legitimacy of presidential elections.

Given how polarized our politics are, I think it’s time to move away from the Electoral College and toward a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. As someone who values fairness and community well-being, it bothers me that campaigns focus on a handful of swing states while ignoring most voters. A system where the candidate with the most votes actually wins would feel more democratic and could help restore some trust in our elections.

As a teacher and a mom, I want my kids to grow up in a country where every vote truly counts the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least reformed so that electoral votes are awarded proportionally instead of winner-take-all. That would make candidates pay attention to all communities—including Latino and working families like mine—instead of just a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who cares about social justice, it doesn’t feel fair that a few swing states get so much power while a lot of people’s votes end up not really mattering. A popular vote system would push candidates to talk to more diverse communities, including people like me, instead of just focusing on certain states.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose by making sure smaller and less populated states aren’t completely steamrolled by the big coastal cities, so I wouldn’t support abolishing it. That said, I’d be open to reforms that improve transparency and public confidence, like tightening rules around faithless electors or standardizing how states allocate their electors, as long as we keep the basic structure that protects federalism and the voice of different regions.

As a counselor and a Catholic committed to social justice, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, regardless of where they live. The current system can drown out the voices of people in non–battleground states and can even result in presidents who lose the popular vote, which feels fundamentally unfair and undermines trust in our democracy.

As someone who believes in social justice and community voice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter where they live. The current system makes some states and communities matter more than others, which doesn’t sit right with my values of fairness and inclusion. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to people in all communities—rural, urban, and suburban—instead of just a handful of swing states.

As someone who came to this country from Nigeria and believes deeply in democracy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. It doesn’t make sense to me that a few swing states get all the attention while millions of votes elsewhere are essentially sidelined. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to the real diversity of America—immigrants, Black communities, and working people like me—instead of tailoring everything to a handful of states.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and less populated states like many across the heartland, instead of letting only big coastal cities decide everything. If anything, we should focus on tightening election integrity—like consistent voter ID and clear rules in every state—rather than overhauling a system that has helped keep our republic balanced for over two centuries.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but with some reforms to make it feel fairer and more responsive. A system like what Maine and Nebraska use, where electoral votes are partly based on congressional districts and partly statewide, could give people in rural areas like where I’m from more of a voice while still respecting the balance between big and small states.

As a constitutional conservative and a practicing lawyer, I view the Electoral College as an essential safeguard of federalism and a protection against pure majoritarianism that would allow a few large states and urban centers to dominate national politics. I would oppose abolishing it, but I am open to modest, constitutionally sound reforms—such as encouraging more states to adopt a district-based allocation of electors like Maine and Nebraska—to better reflect regional preferences without undermining the balance between states and the national popular will.

My mom tells me that when people vote for president, sometimes the one with more people liking him still doesn’t win because of something called the Electoral College, and that feels a little unfair to me. I think it would be better if every person’s vote just counted the same no matter where they live, like when we all get one turn in a game and it really counts. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so the person who gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country is the one who wins.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t feel fair that someone in a small state can have more power than a lot of people in a big state, because my teachers say fairness means everyone gets an equal say. Maybe we could just add up all the votes in the whole country and whoever gets the most wins, like when we vote for class president.

Given how divided our country feels, I believe we need a system that makes every vote count equally, no matter where you live. I’d support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote so the candidate who wins the most votes actually becomes president, or at least reforming it so electoral votes are allocated proportionally rather than winner-take-all. That would encourage candidates to pay attention to all communities—including quieter, rural, and small-town places like many we have here in Colorado—rather than just a handful of swing states.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller and more rural states like Kansas aren’t totally drowned out by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-based system but better reflect the popular vote, like allocating electors by congressional district or adding safeguards so that close national races don’t hinge on just one or two “swing” states.

As a naturalized citizen who worked hard to build a small cleaning business, I believe the Electoral College should be kept but updated, not eliminated. It protects the voice of smaller states and people outside the big cities, but I would support reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or requiring states to follow clearer, uniform rules so elections feel more fair and transparent.

Given my background in healthcare administration, I’m acutely aware of how systems can become outdated and unresponsive if they don’t adapt, and I see the Electoral College in a similar light. I would support moving to a national popular vote or at least reforming the system—such as adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—so that every vote counts equally, regardless of state. This would make our elections more democratic and transparent, and reduce the outsized influence of a handful of swing states.

Coming from a small-town Tennessee background and caring a lot about fairness and representation, I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, no matter what state you’re in. The current system makes a handful of swing states way too powerful and sidelines issues I care about, like climate action and sustainable policy, because candidates chase Electoral College math instead of the actual majority of voters.

As someone who runs her own business and has seen firsthand how diverse our country is—through both my guests and my travels—I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote. Ogni voto dovrebbe contare allo stesso modo, no matter where you live, so that presidents are chosen by the clear will of the majority rather than by a handful of swing states. At the very least, we should move to a system that allocates electoral votes proportionally within each state to better reflect the real preferences of voters.

At my age, having watched a lot of elections come and go, I still think the Electoral College serves an important purpose in forcing candidates to pay attention to smaller and less populous states, not just the big coastal cities. That said, I’d support some modest reforms—like allocating electors by congressional district or tightening rules around “faithless electors”—to make the system feel a bit fairer and more transparent, without scrapping a structure that has generally kept the country stable for over two centuries.

As someone who believes deeply in fairness and social justice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot is truly equal, no matter where a person lives. Coming from Canada, I’ve always found it troubling that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, which feels undemocratic and discouraging for many communities. A direct vote would make leaders more accountable to all citizens, not just those in a few swing states.

As someone who cares a lot about fairness and participation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter if you live in North Dakota or New York. In my work, details matter, and it frustrates me that a candidate can "win" the presidency while losing the popular vote—it's like building a house on a skewed foundation. A modern democracy should reflect the will of the majority directly, while still protecting voting rights and access for all communities.

As someone who chose to make a life in the U.S. and cares deeply about fairness and every voice counting, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote. It doesn’t feel just that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, especially when so many people—like permanent residents and other non-citizens—are already on the margins of political power. A popular vote system would push candidates to engage all communities, including immigrant and working-class neighborhoods, instead of just “swing states.” That kind of reform would move us closer to the social justice and equality I try to live out in my work and volunteer life.

At my age, I’ve come to respect the wisdom of the Founders, and I believe the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and preventing a few big cities from dominating national elections. That said, I would support modest reforms that increase transparency and ensure states run their elections cleanly and consistently, perhaps by standardizing some procedures. I’m wary of rushing into a national popular vote, which I fear could deepen divisions and invite even more chaos and legal battles. Instead, we should focus on tightening election integrity and improving civic education so people better understand why the system exists in the first place.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced by a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. As someone who works hard, talks to all kinds of people, and sees how different folks struggle, it doesn’t sit right with me that a few swing states get all the attention while most voters are basically ignored. A popular vote would push candidates to campaign everywhere, listen to more diverse communities, and actually earn support from the majority of Americans.

Given my background in sales and construction, I’m a big believer in straightforward systems where everyone’s voice counts equally, so I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote. It doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote—one person, one vote should mean the same thing in Illinois as it does in any other state.

As someone who grew up learning about our system in school and believes in tradition, I think the Electoral College should be preserved, but it could use some careful, modest reforms. I’d like to see changes that encourage candidates to pay more attention to smaller and rural states, maybe by proportional allocation of electoral votes, without moving to a pure popular vote that would let big cities dominate everyone else.

I think the person who gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country should be the president, because that feels the most fair, like when we vote in class and the person with the most hands up wins. It confuses me that someone can win even if more people voted for the other person, so I’d change the rules so every vote everywhere matters the same.

As a young Black guy from Jersey who really cares about community voices being heard, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. Right now, candidates focus on a few swing states and ignore a lot of communities like mine, and that just doesn’t feel democratic. A popular vote system would push politicians to reach out to more diverse neighborhoods and actually earn support from people across the whole country.

I’m not a fan of the Electoral College as it stands, because it feels like some votes end up counting more than others depending on what state you live in, and that rubs me the wrong way as someone who believes in personal responsibility and fairness. I’d support moving toward a national popular vote or at least proportional allocation of electoral votes within each state, so every ballot matters equally instead of everything hinging on a handful of “swing” states.

As someone who deeply believes in equal opportunities and one person, one vote, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College. It doesn’t sit right with me that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes, and it makes some states (like mine in Oklahoma) feel like they barely matter in presidential campaigns. A popular vote system would encourage candidates to speak to all Americans, not just swing-state voters, and better reflect the will of the people while still respecting our constitutional framework through a carefully designed reform or amendment.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College is an anachronism that distorts the popular will and over-empowers a handful of swing states. I would favor replacing it with a national popular vote, possibly with ranked-choice voting, so that every ballot is weighed equally and candidates must appeal to citizens across the entire country, not just to strategic pockets.

As someone who became a citizen by choice, I’d like to see reforms that make every vote feel equally powerful, no matter what state you live in—something like a national popular vote or a proportional allocation of electors. The current Electoral College makes a few swing states far too important and can leave many communities, including immigrants and young families like mine, feeling sidelined.

I think we should keep the Electoral College, but maybe modernize parts of it so people feel their vote really matters, like making the rules more consistent across states. The system helps make sure smaller and rural states like New Mexico still have a voice and aren’t drowned out by big cities on the coasts. Instead of scrapping it, we should focus on cleaning up elections, making them more secure and transparent, and improving civics education so folks actually understand how it works.

I think the president should be picked by whoever gets the most votes from all the people, because that feels the fairest and easiest to understand. Since my family moved from Africa and my parents teach me that everyone’s voice matters, it seems wrong if someone wins even when more people voted for someone else. If they keep the Electoral College, they should at least change it so every state gives its electoral votes based on the exact share of people’s votes, so fewer people feel left out.

I’d like to see the Electoral College reformed, not scrapped. I think we should keep the state-by-state system so smaller and rural states like where I’m from don’t get steamrolled by big cities, but I’d support changes like awarding electors proportionally or by congressional district so every vote feels like it counts more. A system that encourages candidates to visit and listen to people in all parts of the country—urban, suburban, and rural—would be better for the long-term stability and fairness of our democracy.

I think the Electoral College needs to be reformed, but not scrapped entirely. A system like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact or proportional allocation of electors by state could keep smaller states and rural areas—places like where I enjoy spending time outdoors—from being totally ignored, while still ensuring that the candidate who wins the most votes nationwide actually wins the presidency.

Given how closely divided our country is and how much I value every person’s voice, I think we should move to a national popular vote for president so that the candidate who gets the most votes actually wins. The Electoral College might have made sense in the 18th century, but today it distorts campaigns around a handful of swing states and makes many voters—rural or urban—feel like their vote doesn’t matter. I’d support either a constitutional amendment to replace it outright or, at the very least, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact that push us toward “one person, one vote” in practice.
